This was to ensure that taxes were not increased when corporations' payrolls decreased, which many corporate owners faced as part of the tax cut Lumumba faced.  The banking industry has contrasted the tax cut with high primary rates, charging such firms more with corporate income or the ability to defer taxes on foreign income, as some officials argue maximizing profit margins in these subsidiaries over the taxes they actually paid. Under 100 words is a good title length.<n><n>### Input:<n>A major advantage of DNA vaccination is the ability to induce both humoral and cellular immune responses. DNA vaccines are currently used in veterinary medicine, but have not achieved widespread acceptance for use in humans due to their low immunogenicity in early clinical studies. However, recent clinical data have re-established the value of DNA vaccines, particularly in priming high-level antigenspecific antibody responses. Several approaches have been investigated for improving DNA vaccine efficacy, including advancements in DNA vaccine vector design, the inclusion of genetically engineered cytokine adjuvants, and novel non-mechanical delivery methods. These strategies have shown promise, resulting in augmented adaptive immune responses in not only mice, but also in large animal models. Here, we review advancements in each of these areas that show promise for increasing the immunogenicity of DNA vaccines.<n><n>### Response:<n>		Among these, DNA vaccines have been shown to induce both humoral (priming high-level antigeogen antibody responses) and cellular immune responses. In addition, recent clinical data have documented that the efficacy of DNA vaccines is significant, including in mice. Here we review eleven approaches for increasing the immunogenity of DNA vaccines.

Your task is to generate a headline for that article.<n><n>### Input:<n>A Standing Committee for Foodstuffs (hereinafter called the 'Committee') is hereby set up and shall consist of representatives of the Member States with a representative of the Commission as Chairman. The Committee shall, in the cases and under the conditions provided for therein, carry out the duties devolving upon it under the instruments relating to foodstuffs adopted by the Council.It may, moreover, consider any other question arising under such instruments and referred to it by its Chairman either on his own initiative or at the request of a Member State. The Committee shall adopt its own rules of procedure.<n><n>### Response:<n>		Article 1. In the case of the European Food Safety Authority, the Commitee for Foodstuffs meets on the first Saturday of October each year and submits the reports from the inspections carried out during the preceding months (the Inspectorate Period). At 2.30 pm on each subsequent Saturday the Committee pro tempore, who chairs the meeting, prepares the report. The report is then put before the Committee at 2.45 pm, maintaining 24 hour recomposition throughout the year.<n><n>Article 2. The Committee approves or refuses to accept any report which it finds unacceptable or contrary to the rules. In case any such report should concern the safety of European products, it adopts the necessary measures. The Investigatory Chamber will use its power of instruction on the Regulations Committee, or its equivalent as a supervisory body for the members of the Committee, to annul the decision.<n><n>The Committee shall undertake a review dependent on the report of the Review Chamber. When so referred, it may reach a decision under Article 16(4)<n><n>(4)<n>which withdraws its decision.<n><n>Article 3. The Committee considers any emergency situation arising on its territory, which may require its intervention. It adopts the necessary measures and makes recommendations in prescribed form

Preferred headlines are under fifteen words.<n><n>### Input:<n>We present DEFEXT, an easy to use semi supervised Definition Extraction Tool. DEFEXT is designed to extract from a target corpus those textual fragments where a term is explicitly mentioned together with its core features, i.e. its definition. It works on the back of a Conditional Random Fields based sequential labeling algorithm and a bootstrapping approach. Bootstrapping enables the model to gradually become more aware of the idiosyncrasies of the target corpus. In this paper we describe the main components of the toolkit as well as experimental results stemming from both automatic and manual evaluation. We release DEFEXT as open source along with the necessary files to run it in any Unix machine. We also provide access to training and test data for immediate use.<n><n>### Response:<n>		Defext automates the definition of a word or a paragraph (full text) in an electronic publication.<n>Defext automatically generates the headline(s) for under fifteen words (with optional footnotes).<n>The full text can still be simply read without the synthetic facilities, but the artificial language feature identified in the text from the primary text could be ignored, leaving only the read-then-label instructions.<n>To build a summary of these results, we recommend a 3-3.5 summary of these activities together, with full descriptions of the classification algorithm, manual training data, and bootstrapping of the model.<n>Please cite the original paper when using DEFEXT. This can also be done manually using the authors' Directions online.

Blanks are special tokens that can replace words and phrases that contain blanks.

Preferred titles are under thirty words.<n><n>### Input:<n>Hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) develop during embryogenesis in a complex process that involves multiple anatomical sites. Once HSC precursors have been specified from mesoderm, they have to mature into functional HSCs and undergo self-renewing divisions to generate a pool of HSCs. During this process, developing HSCs migrate through various embryonic niches, which provide signals for their establishment and the conservation of their self-renewal ability. These processes have to be recapitulated to generate HSCs from embryonic stem cells. Elucidating the interactions between developing HSCs and their niches should facilitate the generation and expansion of HSCs in vitro to exploit their clinical potential.<n><n>### Response:<n>		The Hematopoietic Stem Cell Line (HSCs) establish self-renewal in a complex process involving multiple anatomical sites involving the mesoderm, the   endoderm, the  thymus, and finally the extracellular matrix. The goal is to generate functional HSCs that will assist in the developmental of HSCs that will be required for the treatment of patients with various diseases such as infertility, and to uncover the disturbances that lead to infertility. This process has to be recreated in enriched circumstances. Examples of realistic and detailed evolutionary models could be our new knowledge about the differentiation process and how HSCs are regulated in the  enteroendocrine and pituitary regions. Finally, studying the interactions between HSCs and their epithelium represent a case study in the trafficking of HSCs coming from the  endoderm to the thymus.

The particles can transport over long distance and cause long-range infections due to its light weight. We suggest a mode which is droplet combining with aerosol mode. Inventors of this process include the Chinese, Egyptians, Mesopotamians, Austronesian tribes, and many others.<n><n>By the 1800s, very advanced methods were employed to separate the flowing energy from the source material. Reports so far suggest that it is a progressive or at least a stationary condition. There are no detailed reports on recommended therapy. A prospective clinical study was conducted to show regression of LK following extracapsular cataract extraction. Seventeen black patients (26 eyes) with LK and mature cataracts underwent extracapsular cataract extraction. The severity of the LK was recorded photographically pre- and postoperatively. The follow-up ranged from 6 to fifteen months. Twenty-four eyes (92%) showed regression of the LK. The reduction in exposure to ultraviolet light as a result of aphakic photophobia could be one of the factors which have led to the regression of the LK.<n><n>### Response:<n>		The study was conducted to show that retinal villous atrophy, which is thought to be the etiology of LK, is a progressive or at the least a stationary condition.

Fifty one subjects with altered levels of consciousness were studied. Of these, 23 patients were known diabetics, and 28 were not diabetic. The change in glucose level for the total study group ranged from a low of 37 mg/dl to a high of 370 mg/dl, with a mean of 166 +/- 77 mg/dl. The mean for the diabetic and non-diabetic groups were 177 +/- 80 mg/dl and 154 +/- 75 mg/dl. These results suggest that serum glucose levels cannot be quantitatively predicted after a single intravenous bolus of D-50.<n><n>### Response:<n>		They found that after 50 ml of 50% D-50 (100 mg) in the emergency department, serum glucose levels rose by 17%.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>Given a real-life anecdote of a complex ethical situation, generate a suitable title that describes the main event/root cause of the situation. Imagine that the given text is a social media post, and you have to write the title of the post, so the users can decide to read the main text or not.<n><n>### Input:<n>So I shop at Target and wanted to create an account since I wanted to buy something online. I went to register my email like anyone who created a new account would and a notification popped up saying an account had already been created. So i thought that I might have already created one in the past and forgot about it. Because of this I went ahead and reset the password and it turns out someone else had created it. I just went ahead and deleted their information and replaced it with my own. I thought I was doing something right but it was brought to my attention that I should have reported it instead. Am I the asshole because I just took it over and didn't submit a report or anything? <n><n>### Response:<n>		The main text says Target was the wrong store for me to create an account. I was supposed to register to create an account when I first contacted the store and the account was already created. The main text also states that after I hesitated to delete the information from the account, they subsequently sent me a new email promising that their account was now safe. <n><n>The words "target was the wrong store" also appear in two different drafts of the same paragraph. The initial draft only mentions the store, while the second draft makes changes to the text and adds "was also wrong".<n><n>The company engaged a high profile PR firm to investigate. Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>Given an abstract of a paper, generate a title for this paper such that conveys the key focus of the paper.<n><n>### Input:<n>Abstract: The histamine releasing potential of equivalent bolus doses of atracurium 0.6 mg kg-1 or vecuronium 0.12 mg kg-1 was evaluated in 20 children anaesthetized with halothane. Blood samples were obtained before, and at 2 and 5 min after the administration of the neuromuscular blocker. The twitch response to 0.15 Hz was also evaluated. None of the 10 patients receiving vecuronium had a significant increase in plasma histamine concentration. In two of the 10 children receiving atracurium, the plasma histamine concentration increased markedly, but without any apparent clinical manifestations. Recovery of neuromuscular function (to 95% twitch height) after vecuronium 0.12 mg kg-1 was faster than after atracurium 0.6 mg kg-1 (P less than 0.02).<n><n>### Response:<n>		The results show for 20 children anaesthetizing with halothane and 2 and 5 min after administration of the neuromutcular blocker that none of the 10 patients receiving the neuromutcular inhibitor had a significant increase in the plasma histamine concentration. Furthermore, recovery of neuromuscular functional (to 95% twitch strength) was faster than for the control group, which is also without any apparent clinical manifestations, indicating that the administered bolus dose was not capable of inducing a significant rise in plasma histamine concentration in the absence of apparent clinical signs.

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>Given an abstract of a paper, generate a title for this paper such that conveys the key focus of the paper.<n><n>### Input:<n>Abstract: This study evaluated train-of-four recovery after the administration of vecuronium, comparing measured with visually observed responses. Responses to supramaximal stimuli of the ulnar nerves were measured by a force transducer, and compared with visually observed movements of the contralateral thumb. For the 10 patients anaesthetized with nitrous oxide and enflurane, the second, third and fourth twitches visually reappeared at 84 (+/- 10)%, 76 (+/- 11)%, and 70 (+/- 12)% measured blockade, respectively. For the other 10 patients, anaesthetized with a narcotic-barbiturate technique, the second, third and fourth twitches reappeared at 81 (+/- 8)%, 68 (+/- 9)%, and 59 (+/- 11)%. These results were not different for the two anaesthetic techniques.<n><n>### Response:<n>		Vecuronium is a powerful antibiotic that can make a difference for the body. In this study, the pharmacological administration of vecuronica reduced the number of twitches observed by the control group but did not affect the recorded responses of the muscles. Both the control and the deprived rat groups showed significant reductions in the mean strength of the ulnar muscles, which may suggest that management of the disease involves slowing down the voluntary movement of the muscles.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>In this task you are given a list of triplets of the form [subject, predicate, object] and the output should be a question based on the triplets but with the subject and/or object replaced with blanks (represented using two or more consecutive underscores). Triplet values encompassed in [*] are special tokens that can be replaced with synonyms. The objective is to construct a question in a manner that (a) captures the facts specified in at least one of the triplets, and (b) ideally contains a limited number of blanks such that it is a well-formed question that is easy to answer. A blank can represent a single word or a phrase.<n><n>### Input:<n>[['Accademia di Architettura di Mendrisio', 'COUNTRY', 'Switzerland'], ['Switzerland', 'LEADER_NAME', 'Johann Schneider-Ammann'], ['Switzerland', 'LEADER_TITLE', 'Federal Chancellor of Switzerland']]<n><n>### Response:<n>		Johann Schneider-ammann, The Federal Chancellor of Switzerland

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>In this task, you will be given a short story. One sentence from the story is chosen. Consider the events that happen before that sentence, or are likely to have happened before it. Does any of them directly cause it, or simply make it possible? You should write your answer in the form " A >causes/enables> B". Try to use phrases and sentences from the story to compose your answer when possible.<n><n>### Input:<n>story: Beth was at the Emergency room due to an illness which lasted days. The doctor came into the room and told her was simply a flu. He gave her an iv for nausea, and fluids. After 2 hours she felt a lot better. Her mother was relieved it was not serious.<n> selected sentence: Beth was at the Emergency room due to an illness which lasted days.<n><n>### Response:<n>		Beth was at the Emergency room because of an illness which lasted days (or could have happened).<n><n>A direct result of the illness is that Beth was unable to attend a work meeting. The doctor gave her an iv for lack of nausea, and fluids.<n><n>The expression "just a flu" comes from the narration of this passage. The phrase itself only directly causes the illness, as Beth's condition did not persist despite the efforts of the doctor and her mother. The, "lies" do not directly cause her to be unable to work, as she detailed her symptoms during the emergency room visit.

However, experts agree that a continent with so much potential - with an eye to building sustainable economies and creating jobs - is a continent ripe for sustained growth. Africa offers, along with Asia and Latin America, a vast swathe of land, oceans, biodiversity, warm climates, diverse cultural heritage and strong human rights. Overcoming these challenges will require extensive, coordinated and focused partnerships across governmental, civil society and the private sector. These teams will aim to promote and be part of a growing trend that is helping Africa break out of its deep economic malaise as well as increasing its ability to attract global investors and start new businesses.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>Convert a disfluent question to a proper question. A disfluent question is a question that has some interruptions in it while framing. A proper question is the correct form of the question without any disfluency.<n><n>### Input:<n>What type actually what committee corresponds with one or more departments in the Spanish Government?<n><n>### Response:<n>		The Spanish Government is a legislative body with a main legislative function of determining the fiscal policy of Spain. The legislative body consists of 15 Deputies and 3 senators, alongside representatives from the executive branch, the finance authorities and other legal groups. The legislative body adopt the framework of the country's current union budget on behalf of the government, alongside negotiations with other central government agencies, interest groups and tax authorities. The legislative body regulates the jurisdiction of the civil courts, ensures compliance with the official tax enactments and allows the treatment of gains and losses through the tax system.

Here we develop a Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method for estimating epidemiological parameters of the 2001 outbreak for a range of simple transmission models. We make the simplifying assumption that infectious farms were completely observed in 2001, equivalent to assuming that farms that were proactively culled but not diagnosed with FMD were not infectious, even if some were infected. We estimate how transmission parameters varied through time, highlighting the impact of the control measures on the progression of the epidemic. We demonstrate statistically significant evidence for assortative contact patterns between animals of the same species. Predictive risk maps of the transmission potential in different geographic areas of GB are presented for the fitted models.<n><n>### Response:<n>		According to the research paper, the following title would be appropriate:<n>2001 Foot and Mouth Disease (FMD) – Explaining the Epidemiology in a Simplified Model

Consider the events that happen before that sentence, or are likely to have happened before it. Does any of them directly cause it, or simply make it possible? You should write your answer in the form " A >causes/enables> B". Try to use phrases and sentences from the story to compose your answer when possible.<n><n>### Input:<n>story: It was a cloudy day outside. Tina thought that it would rainy outside. She brought her umbrella with her on the bus. Tina lost her umbrella on the bus. She got rained on as she walked to work.<n> selected sentence: Tina thought that it would rainy outside.<n><n>### Response:<n>		A >causes/enabling> B

The objective is to construct a question in a manner that (a) captures the facts specified in at least one of the triplets, and (b) ideally contains a limited number of blanks such that it is a well-formed question that is easy to answer. A proper question is the correct form of the question without any disfluency.<n><n>### Input:<n>The presence or  absence of who no I mean of what can be used to determine the relative age of the formations in which they are found?<n><n>### Response:<n>		One way to determine if the formations in question are young is to determine how much older they are than when the question is framed. Then, we can determine the approximate age of the formations in question. <n><n>In alternative circumstances, we can also calculate the total number of adjacent standing connections in a PEMD cluster using the starting age of the core. This method does not require SMPTEs. However, if in the PEMD cluster, we have started with such small groups of nodes (fragments), using the old approach we would have to generate some very dense clusters over a longer time.<n><n>Return to top<n><n>Objectives<n>- Portray the construction of matrix as  arrest and the subsequent escape of the protagonist opposite the intervention of force. If the protagonist is facing forward causes superior force to rise -- avoid arrest.<n>- Make connections between measures exploiting the arrest counter as a strong reverse opposite of the reverse force incident

This observation does not invalidate the concept of functional groupings within these anterior horn cell pools. Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>In this task you are given a list of triplets of the form [subject, predicate, object] and the output should be a question based on the triplets but with the subject and/or object replaced with blanks (represented using two or more consecutive underscores). Triplet values encompassed in [*] are special tokens that can be replaced with synonyms. The objective is to construct a question in a manner that (a) captures the facts specified in at least one of the triplets, and (b) ideally contains a limited number of blanks such that it is a well-formed question that is easy to answer. A blank can represent a single word or a phrase.<n><n>### Input:<n>[['1950-51', 'LEAGUE', 'Main League'], ['Main League', 'SILVER', 'Odd']]<n><n>### Response:<n>		In the text you provided the Blanks can represent sentences or phrases. To derive a logical question from the example, you can substitute [*this word or phrase] with [*the word or phrase that has the triplets replaced with blanks]. This method can be used to provide contextually misleading answers to simple questions. A good example of such a question is when trying to figure out whether a bowling alley contains cat poop (a single word). Assuming your guess is correct (which is highly probable), "A bowling alley with cat poop as the designated name is likely a cat den." There is “no logical connection between man and cat — just feces.”<n>Half the fun of dumb answers is not uncovering details of the nature of the alley world, but keeping from concluding that a cat den exists.<n><n>In the text, the subject and object are strings while the answer is a question.

This dynamic structure physically connects neighboring epithelial cells, couples intercellular adhesive contacts to the cytoskeleton, and helps define each cell's apical-basal axis. Together these activities coordinate the form, polarity, and function of all cells in an epithelium. Several molecules regulate AJ formation and integrity, including Rho family GTPases and Par polarity proteins. However, only recently, with the development of live-cell imaging, has the extent to which E-cadherin is actively turned over at junctions begun to be appreciated. This turnover contributes to junction formation and to the maintenance of epithelial integrity during tissue homeostasis and remodeling.<n><n>### Response:<n>		My friend Mike, thanks for the link, that really helped me understand this molecule. Mapping such syntactic variants into semantic concepts that can be understood by robots is challenging due to the high flexibility of natural language expressions. To tackle this problem, we collect robotic commands for navigation and manipulation tasks using crowdsourcing. We further define a robot language and use a generative machine translation model to translate robotic commands from natural language to robot language. The main purpose of this paper is to simulate the interaction process between human and robots using crowdsourcing platforms, and investigate the possibility of translating natural language to robot language with paraphrases.<n><n>### Response:<n>		Navigation and manipulation tasks<n>Robotic commands in organic as well as natural language typically contain spatial descriptions that are semotically similar but syntactically differ. Mapping such syntactically variants into semantic concepts that could be understood by robots is difficult given the high flexibility of natural lexical constructs. To tackle this problem using interactions with humans, we collect robotic commands and translate them into robot language using crowdsourcing platforms.

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>In this task, you are given a part of an article. Your task is to generate headline (title) for this text. Preferred headlines are under fifteen words.<n><n>### Input:<n>We propose zoneout, a novel method for regularizing RNNs. At each timestep, zoneout stochastically forces some hidden units to maintain their previous values. Like dropout, zoneout uses random noise to train a pseudo-ensemble, improving generalization. But by preserving instead of dropping hidden units, gradient information and state information are more readily propagated through time, as in feedforward stochastic depth networks. We perform an empirical investigation of various RNN regularizers, and find encouraging results: zoneout gives significant performance improvements across tasks, yielding state-ofthe-art results in character-level language modeling on the Penn Treebank dataset and competitive results on word-level Penn Treebank and permuted sequential MNIST classification tasks.<n><n>### Response:<n>		zoneout is an interesting RNN regularizer that yields impressive results. You can find more information about it in the paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/20171119jsc.

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. To make encoder-decoder models more flexible, attention mechanism was introduced to machine translation and also other tasks like speech recognition and image captioning. We observe that the quality of translation by attention-based encoder-decoder can be significantly damaged when the alignment is incorrect. We attribute these problems to the lack of distortion and fertility models. Aiming to resolve these problems, we propose new variations of attention-based encoderdecoder and compare them with other models on machine translation. Our proposed method achieved an improvement of 2 BLEU points over the original attentionbased encoder-decoder.<n><n>### Response:<n>		Neural machine Translation has shown very promising results recently. Most NMT models following the encoder-decoders framework. To make encoders more flexible, attention mechanism  was introduced to machine translation, and also other tasks like voice recognition and image captioning. We observe that the quality issue of translation by attention- based encododer-decoder can occurs because of the lack of distortion and infertility models. We attribute these problems of machine translation to the lack of distortion, low entropy, and the lack of fertility models. Aiming the improvement of 2 BLEUE points above the original interest rates is in AI, but with very high power, sensitivity, and correctness.<n><n>Here is a summary of our results:

Add radicchio, radishes, and apples to bowl; toss gently to coat. Place about 3/4 cup salad on each of 8 plates; sprinkle each serving with 1 1/2 teaspoons nuts.'<n><n>### Response:<n>		Mix 1 tablespoon of the orange juice, 1 tablespoon of walnut oil, and 1 tablespoon of red wine vinegar in a bowl, stirring. Then stir in 1 tablespoon of Dijon mustard and 1 tablespoon of fresh ground black pepper. Finally, toss gently to coat. Stack the radicchio/radishes onto the salad plates. Turn the radicchio to a plate and dig in. Check with a utensil and if it sticks to the plate. If it does not slide into the plate, sprinkle about 1/2 teaspoon of coarsely chopped walnuts on the plate. Fold the tablespoon of dressing into the salad. Finally, dice up 1/4 cup of granny Smith apple.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>In this task, you're given an ambiguous question (which can be answered in more than one way). Your task is to write a question that clarifies the given question in such a way that the generated question has one unique answer.<n><n>### Input:<n>Where do historians believe the black death originated?<n><n>### Response:<n>		The Black Death is thought to have originated in the region of the Elbe in Germany between the 8th and 11th centuries. There is little evidence to support the time period or location of the Black Death, with evidence observed first in the region around the 8th century (this includes the famous burial sites of Bernhard, Schönborn, and others). Additionally, leading historians believe infectious disease likely played a role in determining the geographic location of the Black Death. E.g. infectious diseases such as the plague were likely spread from Germany to other parts of Europe by boat in such medieval trade routes as the Iberian peninsula.

Since the leaves of this plant are used widely throughout its native area as the source of a mildly stimulant narcotic, the effect in these cases may be an idiosyncratic reaction to an unusually large dose.<n><n>### Response:<n>		The main focus of the paper is on the pharmacological mechanism underlying this reaction. Catha edulis is a medicinal plant used widely throughout its native region as the source of a mild stimulant narcotic. Its leaves are chewed as a means to treat a wide range of diseases and are a popular source of abuse among long-term users. The efficacy of the leaves in treating such conditions is under review, with some evidence suggesting the efficacy of the leaves in the treatment of signature diseases such as idiopathic optic atrophy, although it could also be a side effect of the drug itself.

Your summary should be less than 20 words long.<n><n>### Input:<n>Warner Music owner Len Blavatnik is Britain's richest man with a £13.17bn fortune, according to the 2015 Sunday Times Rich List.<n><n>### Response:<n>		Lennard Pfaster, the founder of Warner Music, has become one of the richest men in the world after purchasing the music business from his father.<n><n>Pfaster, 63, was born 240 miles west of New York and educated in the Swiss industrial south before building a multi-billion fortune by acquiring his parents — a theatre tycoon — in the 1920s. He donated the majority of his fortune to charity following his death in 2011.<n><n>At his peak, imaginative, secretive and demanding, Pfaster built his empire by co-founding MGM and eventually expanding into film (MGM-US), television then publishing King's Cross Records. He was the Music Secretary for 27 years from 1981 to 2006, from 1997 to 2007, before being appointed Hollywood's richest man in 2003.<n><n>Blavatnik paid $13.17bn for Warner Music, the largest single purchase in history. It was a transformational moment for social commentary and entertainment. Titles such as Don't Ask, Don't Tell and Happy Mondays were initially designed as ways of highlighting aspects of the family's business rather than specialising on its corporate culture or philanthropic gifts.

She told Me that she recently found out  that she has a baby. I left work early  to go comfort her. <n><n>No direct result related to this sentence. My cousin's faking the result  was flawed. My sister continued to make statements that were directly related to the pregnancy but took place 3 months after the pregnancy. That is, my cousin was attempting to tell me that things had worked out and that I should relax. Not exactly a super useful quandary to be in. (But: please don't copy our answers!)<n><n>Selecting sentence: She kept trying to make me believe that things were okay.<n>Unfortunately, this is not how pregnancy works, and things may still be going south for you. Although it isn't in the story, it makes reference to your sister hinting at something very bad happening to you.<n><n>B -> Unable to argue with her. -> Why else would you call me?<n>she may have misquoted me

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>In this task, you are given a part of an article. Your task is to generate headline (title) for this text. Preferred headlines are under fifteen words.<n><n>### Input:<n>This paper formulates a novel problem on graphs: find the minimal subset of edges in a fully connected graph, such that the resulting graph contains all spanning trees for a set of specified subgraphs. This formulation is motivated by an unsupervised grammar induction problem from computational linguistics. We present a reduction to some known problems and algorithms from graph theory, provide computational complexity results, and describe an approximation algorithm.<n><n>### Response:<n>		In this task you are given a part in an article about graphs. Your task is to find the minimum subset of edges in a graph such that the resulting graph has the text "all spanning trees". Most headlines generate from a labeled sequence of nodes, so you can target this search in a deep text-based environment. Ideally, you want to avoid similar problems in your subsequent iteration: cluster the graph for more extensive patterns.<n>The preferred method is to use the fuzzy graph algorithm I described and use two dimensions of graph and of the Flexible Graph Calculus library (FgCalculus.md) along with some basic principles of graph algorithms (e.g., INe) to find the minimal subset of trees. By combining efficiency and generative models for exploring sparse graph patterns, we are able to arrive at a soft minimum subset.<n>Though incommensurate with the publication date or other circumstances, optimal headlines would only contain title and abstract (e.g., "a fuzzy graph algorithm"). Ideally you will avoid frequent references to the graph, which limits your generator's generative capabilities. Inputs that link to the article such as a topic heading or image are preferably hidden in the text of your best-case headlines.

( Place ) Tulsa, Oklahoma, Sheriff Stanley Glanz declared that the deputy involved in the fatal shooting of Eric Harris has been reassigned to another position, which could lead to additional charges.

A proper question is the correct form of the question without any disfluency.<n><n>### Input:<n>How do socialists think the financial assets no the means of production shouldn't be owned?<n><n>### Response:<n>		Socialists believe the means of production should not be owned. Preferred headlines are under fifteen words.<n><n>### Input:<n>Recently deep neural networks (DNNs) have been used to learn speaker features. However, the quality of the learned features is not sufficiently good, so a complex back-end model, either neural or probabilistic, has to be used to address the residual uncertainty when applied to speaker verification, just as with raw features. This paper presents a convolutional timedelay deep neural network structure (CT-DNN) for speaker feature learning. Our experimental results on the Fisher database demonstrated that this CT-DNN can produce highquality speaker features: even with a single feature (0.3 seconds including the context), the EER can be as low as 7.68%. This effectively confirmed that the speaker trait is largely a deterministic short-time property rather than a long-time distributional pattern, and therefore can be extracted from just dozens of frames.<n><n>### Response:<n>		This example uses text extracted from the journal Nature. You will first train your convolutional neural network on a text that consists of words starting with the word "Recently." The output will be a Twenty-One word title. The final sample contains a topic starting with "Deep Reading." The text contains constrained acoustic patterns which can be trained on the text, and by combining the input and the output, you can generate high-quality output.

These vergence amplitudes are not an artefact of monocular contours provided by the target borders or test instrument and are comparable in range to vergence amplitudes measured clinically with second degree fusion targets in an amblyoscope. Preferred headlines are under fifteen words.<n><n>### Input:<n>Matrix factorization (MF) and Autoencoder (AE) are among the most successful approaches of unsupervised learning. While MF based models have been extensively exploited in the graph modeling and link prediction literature, the AE family has not gained much attention. In this paper we investigate both MF and AE’s application to the link prediction problem in sparse graphs. We show the connection between AE and MF from the perspective of multiview learning, and further propose MF+AE: a model training MF and AE jointly with shared parameters. We apply dropout to training both the MF and AE parts, and show that it can significantly prevent overfitting by acting as an adaptive regularization. We conduct experiments on six real world sparse graph datasets, and show that MF+AE consistently outperforms the competing methods, especially on datasets that demonstrate strong non-cohesive structures.<n><n>### Response:<n>		The author provided the following example of a text that might be used to teach both MF and AE:<n><n>Graphs employing both the MF and AE techniques together produce a very good result:<n><n>Graphs using both the MF and AE approaches together produce a very good  result  <n><n>Inference on structuring under the hood with a sequence of fits

However, for more realistic and more complex models than those assuming homogeneous mixing in the population, other threshold quantities can be defined that are sometimes more useful and easily derived in terms of model parameters. In this paper, we present a model for the spread of a permanently immunizing infection in a population socially structured into households and workplaces/schools, and we propose and discuss a new household-to-household reproduction number R H for it. We show how R H overcomes some of the limitations of a previously proposed threshold parameter, and we highlight its relationship with the effort required to control an epidemic when interventions are targeted at randomly selected households.<n><n>### Response:<n>		The Medical Research Council (MRC) in collaboration with the US Centers for Disease Control and John Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health (BJSHP) has published a research paper titled "A population-based approach to the spread of an infection with a bacterium that causes acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)" that we hope you will consider for publication.

The swimmers who reach the Olympic qualifying mark are then given a clean sheet, and if they are within the shot of achieving the Olympic scoring mark, an automatic bronze medal.

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>In this task you're given a question and you have to paraphrase the question to create the output question while retaining the meaning of the original question.<n><n>### Input:<n>If a die is rolled, what is the probability that the number is greater than 4?<n><n>### Response:<n>		If a die are rolled, what is the likelihood that the number is greater then 4?  Common answers to this question that you will hear repeatedly are 1 in 5, which would give you a 21% probability that the number is less than 4.  This probability is based on a coin flip where each side will put the number of turns before each other to determine the result.  For example 4 comes down to 21, so the probability that it will come down to 4 is 1/5.  <n><n>You can use simple sentence construction to avoid this type of problem by simply using the word roll and phrases like 4-21 to make the question clearer. <n><n>If the die is smaller than 4, what is the probability of it not being equal to 4? <n>This probability can be calculated by rolling the die 6 times and landing on 4 since that is the smallest possible roll result.   For example 4 / 6 = 81% so the probability that the die does not equal 4 (assuming the number of turns before playing a coin flip is equal to 1) is 81% leaving the probability that it equal 4 1/4, meaning 81% — roll 6 times, and your probability of the die not equal 4 is 1/4.

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>In this task, you are given an abstract of article. Your task is to generate title for this article. Preferred titles are under thirty words.<n><n>### Input:<n>T cell activation is predicated on the interaction between the T cell receptor and peptide-major histocompatibility (pMHC) ligands. The factors that determine the stimulatory potency of a pMHC molecule remain unclear. We describe results showing that a peptide exhibiting many hallmarks of a weak agonist stimulates T cells to proliferate more than the wild-type agonist ligand. An in silico approach suggested that the inability to form the central supramolecular activation cluster (cSMAC) could underlie the increased proliferation. This conclusion was supported by experiments that showed that enhancing cSMAC formation reduced stimulatory capacity of the weak peptide. Our studies highlight the fact that a complex interplay of factors determines the quality of a T cell antigen.<n><n>### Response:<n>		T cell activation by PI3K/Akt is strongly dependent on interaction with PEG-1/Akt and its ligands. We now describe direct evidence that PI3K/A activation is impaired by a weak peptide that lacks specific hallmarks of a potent generally active PEG-1/a th2 agonist. A proposed mechanism for this inhibition is suggested by experimental evidence showing that a weak, high-activity PEG-1/α th2 inhibitor inhibits the proliferation of T cell lines constitutent for hypodermic shock. Although a strong negative correlation (r=-.29) was found between the PI3K/A and pMHC activity, these data are diluted by studies of PMH-activated pMHC inhibitory properties. In summary, our data show that a weakly expressed peptide lacks central activation symptoms or physiological activity. As a result, inhibition of T cell activity may be dependent on contributions from complex interplay of factors underlying these observations.

Preferred headlines are under fifteen words.<n><n>### Input:<n>Despite the successes in capturing continuous distributions, the application of generative adversarial networks (GANs) to discrete settings, like natural language tasks, is rather restricted. The fundamental reason is the difficulty of backpropagation through discrete random variables combined with the inherent instability of the GAN training objective. To address these problems, we propose Maximum-Likelihood Augmented Discrete Generative Adversarial Networks. Instead of directly optimizing the GAN objective, we derive a novel and low-variance objective using the discriminator’s output that follows corresponds to the log-likelihood. Compared with the original, the new objective is proved to be consistent in theory and beneficial in practice. The experimental results on various discrete datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.<n><n>### Response:<n>		This task will generate a new and low-variance subject.

However, much is unknown about mechanisms which can give rise to coherent oscillatory behavior, with few exceptions (e.g., explicitly delayed self-repressors and simple models of specific organisms' circadian clocks). We present what may be the simplest possible reliable gene network oscillator, a self-repressing gene. We show that binding cooperativity, which has not been considered in detail in this context, can combine with small numbers of intermediate steps to create coherent oscillation. We also note that noise blurs the line between oscillatory and non-oscillatory behavior.<n><n>### Response:<n>		The structure of a self-reproducing gene network, allowing it to "bend" in such a way that it oscillates enantiomorphically, is a novel mechanism capable of allowing organisms to self-regulate their circadian clock.<n>Indeed, the self-reproducing gene, which is "bent" by a single, local guide, is a useful source of insight into how circadian clock development appears to take place. Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>In this task you're given a question and you have to paraphrase the question to create the output question while retaining the meaning of the original question.<n><n>### Input:<n>Why is circuit switching important?<n><n>### Response:<n>		There are actually several reasons circuit switching is important.  The most common reason is found in semiconductor transistors and in switching mechanisms such as bipolar transistors and piezoelectric transistors.  When one junction is conducting current, the operation of a switch operates by separating the suppression current flowing through the second junction from the current flowing through the first junction.  Conversely, when the active junction is conducting current only a very small amount (typically only a few amperes or milliamps) the suppression current flows through.  As a consequence, the operation of a transistor (within its schematically labeled bipolar transistor) is directed at the desiring rate of the circuit, which is often one transistor at a time, and the then closely follow pruning of sufficient modules to reach the desired output.

The bound in [4] uses Rademacher complexity and has anadditive dependence on the logarithm of the number of kernels and the margin achieved by the classifier. However, there are some errors in parts of the proof which are corrected in this paper. Unfortunately, the final result turns out to be a risk bound which has a multiplicative dependence on the logarithm of the number of kernels and the margin achieved by the classifier.<n><n>### Response:<n>		The generalisation error of classes learned through multiple kernel learning is approximately 0.5, giving rise to bounds which have multiplicative dependence on the number of kernels and not a hazard. Thus, the overall result is risk bound.

The objective is to construct a question in a manner that (a) captures the facts specified in at least one of the triplets, and (b) ideally contains a limited number of blanks such that it is a well-formed question that is easy to answer. A blank can represent a single word or a phrase.<n><n>### Input:<n>[['Clowns', 'eatType', 'coffee shop'], ['Clowns', 'food', 'Japanese'], ['Clowns', 'customer rating', '3 out of 5'], ['Clowns', 'area', 'riverside'], ['Clowns', 'near', 'Clare Hall']]<n><n>### Response:<n>		The first triplet is [Subject, predicate, object] followed by [Clowns, eatType, coffee shop] followed by ['Clowns', customer rating, 3 out of 5']. All products that do not exhibit undesirable characteristics set out in the Annex, shall not be subject to re-imposition or adjustment, and shall enter into force on the date of adoption by the European Parliament and the Council.<n><n>This regulation also sets forth specific conditions for the processing of export refunds. Notification obligations, guidelines for the handling of returned undeclared product results and penalties for non-compliance. The estimated additional burden to European consumers related to the retailing of undeclared product results is estimated at 450 billion Euro in 2022 and to total 578.3 billion Euro by 2021 from 30 May 2020.<n><n>Processing of refunds begins either at raw processing or at a manufacturing facility whereby a small quantity of unrecognized product is treated as undeclared.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>In this task, you are given a part of an article. Your task is to generate headline (title) for this text. Preferred headlines are under fifteen words.<n><n>### Input:<n>State-space models are successfully used in many areas of science, engineering and economics to model time series and dynamical systems. We present a fully Bayesian approach to inference and learning (i.e. state estimation and system identification) in nonlinear nonparametric state-space models. We place a Gaussian process prior over the state transition dynamics, resulting in a flexible model able to capture complex dynamical phenomena. To enable efficient inference, we marginalize over the transition dynamics function and infer directly the joint smoothing distribution using specially tailored Particle Markov Chain Monte Carlo samplers. Once a sample from the smoothing distribution is computed, the state transition predictive distribution can be formulated analytically. Our approach preserves the full nonparametric expressivity of the model and can make use of sparse Gaussian processes to greatly reduce computational complexity.<n><n>### Response:<n>		State-space model was successfully applied in the model training job. At the same time, it is also described how to generate New Timescale-like headlines.

Preferred titles are under thirty words.<n><n>### Input:<n>Air pollution is a heterogeneous, complex mixture of gases, liquids, and particulate matter. Epidemiological studies have demonstrated a consistent increased risk for cardiovascular events in relation to both short- and long-term exposure to present-day concentrations of ambient particulate matter. Several plausible mechanistic pathways have been described, including enhanced coagulation/thrombosis, a propensity for arrhythmias, acute arterial vasoconstriction, systemic inflammatory responses, and the chronic promotion of atherosclerosis. The purpose of this statement is to provide healthcare professionals and regulatory agencies with a comprehensive review of the literature on air pollution and cardiovascular disease. In addition, the implications of these findings in relation to public health and regulatory policies are addressed. Practical recommendations for healthcare providers and their patients are outlined. In the final section, suggestions for future research are made to address a number of remaining scientific questions.<n><n>### Response:<n>		According to this task, you should generate the title for this article. While there is much research that supports the link between air pollution and cardiovascular disease, a comprehensive review of the extant medical literature fails to substantiate the causative relationship. Instead, regulation remains largely apolitical and studies continue to show an increased risk for cardiovascular events related to long-term exposure to air pollutants.

Chest radiographs revealed bilateral diffuse alveolar densities. The patients' symptoms and radiographic findings resolved after several days of supportive care. It’s only known incidence is 2 cases and it’s unclear how many people are affected. No physical sign is useful in the diagnosis of this condition, which should be suspected on the basis of presenting symptoms and confirmed by electrodiagnosis using standard median nerve conduction tests.<n><n>### Response:<n>		Three signs are useful to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome. One is a subjective assessment, possibly with electronics, and the other are classic electrical neuropathological findings, such as a lack of brush and/or trigger fingers and an increased prevalence of facial tenderness and swelling.

In 10 of 15 tests the lesions cleared completely within 1-4 weeks, although some relapses occurred shortly after cessation of treatment. There were no side-effects. We suggest that 1 alpha, 24(OH)2D3 merits further investigation as a potentially useful topical therapy for psoriasis.<n><n>### Response:<n>		1 alpha,24(OH)2D4 is the new synthetic analogue of active Vitamin D3. In 10 out of 15 tests the lesions clearing completely in 1-4 weeks.

The well-paid jobs helped attract many more young people: namely, Afghans who had little access to the formal education system or the nation's formal labor force. Many did not have formal education, but the schools kept educating students. Many continued to be employed in the labor market, because if they were unemployed, their employers wouldn't have the incentive to offer them a better job. In the aftermath of the revolution, many young Afghans gravitated to graft, even though they now faced an uncertain future. Some did return to the country seeking higher-paying jobs. However, some remain very disengaged, preferring to focus on religion or ideologies, as their communities became more unstable and the economy collapsed.

The birth-weights of babies born to women with inflammatory bowel disease were marginally lower than those born to women in a control group matched for age and parity, but the difference was statistically significant only in women with Crohn's disease. In both disease groups there was a higher frequency of low haemoglobin levels in pregnancy than in the matched control groups. There were no statistically significant effects of ulcerative colitis or Crohn's disease on duration of pregnancy, mode of delivery or raised blood pressure and/or proteinuria. In the absence of a relapse, a diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease should not influence obstetric management.<n><n>### Response:<n>		Duration of pregnancy, mode of deliver, raised blood pressure and proteinuria.

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>In this task, we ask you convert a data table of restaurant descriptions into fluent natural-sounding English sentences. The input is a string of key-value pairs; the output should be a natural and grammatical English sentence containing all the information from the input.<n><n>### Input:<n>name[The Punter], priceRange[moderate], area[riverside], familyFriendly[yes], near[The Portland Arms]<n><n>### Response:<n>		> walking<n>> Near the Portland Arms<n>> near The Portland Arms<n><n>If we look closely, we can see that we're not capturing much information from the input: only the first few items in the string are correctly strings. Fortunately, this is a string search engine, so the machine can pick up the differences. The first character is the word, which normally is dropped. We read from the string, and replace the word with the value from the input. But instead of that, we're capturing the first few words and possibly a few patterns during the pattern recognition. That's a good start: now we can drop redundant words in the string and reconstruct the grammar.<n><n>Another technique we can employ is to use another natural language feature: word frequency. When we look at the string against the pattern generated by word frequency, edge cases seem similar to words of our own language. After all, we're trained from English books to search words of our own language alphabetically, which make sense: words that happen frequently in a string will be be highlighted for you. To re-train this on the string, we can use the word per page pattern recognition from stackoverflow.

The embeddings generated by Deep Speaker can be used for many tasks, including speaker identification, verification, and clustering. We experiment with ResCNN and GRU architectures to extract the acoustic features, then mean pool to produce utterance-level speaker embeddings, and train using triplet loss based on cosine similarity. Experiments on three distinct datasets suggest that Deep Speaker outperforms a DNN-based i-vector baseline. For example, Deep Speaker reduces the verification equal error rate by 50% (relatively) and improves the identification accuracy by 60% (relatively) on a text-independent dataset. We also present results that suggest adapting from a model trained with Mandarin can improve accuracy for English speaker recognition.<n><n>### Response:<n>		Teacher identification, verification, and cluster detection using Deep Speaker.

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>In this task, you are given a part of an article. Your task is to generate headline (title) for this text. Preferred headlines are under fifteen words.<n><n>### Input:<n>Colorization of grayscale images has been a hot topic in computer vision. Previous research mainly focuses on producing a colored image to match the original one. However, since many colors share the same gray value, an input grayscale image could be diversely colored while maintaining its reality. In this paper, we design a novel solution for unsupervised diverse colorization. Specifically, we leverage conditional generative adversarial networks to model the distribution of real-world item colors, in which we develop a fully convolutional generator with multi-layer noise to enhance diversity, with multi-layer condition concatenation to maintain reality, and with stride 1 to keep spatial information. With such a novel network architecture, the model yields highly competitive performance on the open LSUN bedroom dataset. The Turing test of 80 humans further indicates our generated color schemes are highly convincible.<n><n>### Response:<n>		A grayscale imaged could match the original grayscale but contain many unique dark regions. However, it would still maintain the object's true color. Our reduced inputs can take care of this by performing recursive face detection. We use our Modular Convolutional Emulation (MCNE) network to generate a variant with condition concatenation and with stride 1. We classify a range of intermediate examples into two clearly different colors.

In the case of small or moderate-size RCTs, a single-sequence randomization method may not ensure balanced allocation between groups. Traditionally a callback is an event-driven mechanism that invokes a callback function as soon as any of the above conditions fail. However, in newer Javascript APIs, some callback functions have other suggested behavior, such as making sure that any future events happen before executing the callback or sending notifications when an event happens.

We develop a robustness metric derived from source-aware lower and upper bounds of model accuracy even when data source labels are not readily available. We clearly demonstrate that even on a well-explored dataset like MNIST, challenging training scenarios can be constructed under the proposed assessment framework for two separate yet equally important applications: i) more rigorous learning model comparison and ii) dataset adequacy evaluation. In addition, our findings not only promise a more complete identification of trade-offs between model complexity, accuracy and robustness but can also help researchers optimize their efforts in data collection by identifying the less robust and more challenging class labels.<n><n>### Response:<n>		We introduce a Novel Resiliently Learning Mapping Framework (NRLMF) to measure the true robusteness of learning models for real world applications by generating sourceinclusive and source exclusive partitions in a dataset via cluster. Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>You will be given three sentences. Read them, then identify a noun phrase (person, place, or thing) or event that is shared between all three sentences. As the output, write the span of the text corresponding to that phrase in each sentence. Keep the order of the sentences, that is, your answer should look like: 1: *a phras from sentence 1e* 2: *a phras from sentence 2* 3: *a phrase from sentence 3*<n><n>### Input:<n>1: ( CNN ) Three British citizens arrested in the United Arab Emirates after they were found plane spotting near Fujairah airport are to be released Monday, their lawyer, Nasser al-Hashem, tells CNN. 2: No charges were filed, there will be no travel ban, and the men will not face deportation, he said. 3: Three British men won't be charged or deported, their lawyer says.<n><n>### Response:<n>		This passage contains two phrases, 'a phras from sentence1' and 'a phrase from sentence2'. We can reconstruct this sentence by splitting the sentence into three sentences (by using key f/w, 'n','m'). <n><n>We can use the supplied sentence as the opening paragraph for identifying a phrase. 'A' is a phrase shared between the sentences, 'place', 'thing', 'ham', 'or', 'uu' as prefix words referencing the main topics discussed in the passage, 'A few words of wisdom' are used as part of the spanish homophonous phrase for 'une advice'. <n><n>We can borrow some linguistic concepts from the English language to reconstruct the sentence. Immediate context is defined by the order of words that follow 'a', 'place', and 'thing', whereas passive context in the USA is classified by that of 'be' followed by the words 'were', 'were', 'were'; 'a man of interest' is as part of a pronominal construction'; and a verbal auxiliary construction is a omission. Finally, 'were' and 'were not' are optional; Ube is optional, Ima is part of a verb, Are is as a word used for both a verb

Comparison of preoperative and postoperative capacities revealed that younger children are considerably less affected by the interruption of callosal transmission than older children. Bilateral organization of speech and participation of the anterior commissure can largely be excluded as possible compensatory mechanisms. The most plausible explanation for the excellent preservation of interhemispheric integration of tactile functions in the younger patients appears to be continued reliance on ipsilateral pathways. The relatively greater deficits observed in the older children, on the other hand, suggest that sensorimotor functions come to depend more extensively on contralateral pathways as the corpus callosum reaches functional maturity.<n><n>### Response:<n>		The 5 children in the study (ages 6 to 16 years) were tested for unilateral discrimination, interhemispheric transfer, and tactuomotor learning. There was evidence that younger children were significantly less impaired by the interruption of callosotomy compared to older children.

Additionally, the market dynamics provides a sensible algorithm for optimising the global objective. As a result, many ordinary people were left with little to look forward to, or even care about. Some sought to earn more money in other countries, on the open market, by trading their skills for labor or other heavily discounted commodities, even if these jobs were often for low-skilled work that would scare away potential suitors. Thousands of small businesses were then set up to cater to the needs of these individuals, providing basic services from the illegal trade of services to residents of other regions. Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>In this task you're given a question and you have to paraphrase the question to create the output question while retaining the meaning of the original question.<n><n>### Input:<n>What's the layman explanation of Godel's incompleteness theorem?<n><n>### Response:<n>		It's simply stated that for any monomorphism category F (x), ∘ x, r (x), f(r), = f(x), where x is the identity category, otherwise the category F(x) includes all monomorphisms between the parties x and r. <n><n>I give a few examples of objects among the list, but you may use phrases like ∘ x ‘ f(x) for many purposes, including this answer...<n><n>A dog is smart, so apparently this definition is incomplete.<n>Or, alternatively the dog must have some additional property (being smart) that enables it to be an exceptional applicative, which means that it might not be a complete definition of intelligent dog.<n><n>To generalize the question, suppose that there is some object ⊗ without a name that we capture by a name (dog in the previous example).  Then this object is also potentially incomplete.<n><n>So the question is basically asking us to say that for any object ⊗ (x), ∘x ‘ f(rr) for all r, unless f(rr) includes some object which perhaps is not dog.

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>Convert a disfluent question to a proper question. A disfluent question is a question that has some interruptions in it while framing. A proper question is the correct form of the question without any disfluency.<n><n>### Input:<n>How many bits are thought to be a hard problem oops are often in the primes used for RSA public key cryptography algorithms?<n><n>### Response:<n>		There are 23 bits in a public key plus an additional 4 bits for the private/key derivation. You can use this number as the hard problem to generate an RSA public key or digest the basic math to generate a random private key. The trick, though unpopular at the time, was to push the difficulty much further by combining the number of bits required to reconstruct the private key with the difficulty of the actual key. This resulted in a well known public key cryptosystem, called Idemitsu 2, which used only 12 bits to generate encryptions. <n><n>You could start by generating a massive amount of random data to start the initial computation. One approach would be to use the Brian Foster algorithm that splits the number of bits required for a solution into two halves - one first bits, err bits, then tails. Secondly make sure you can reduce the total number of string bits used to get one of sufficient lengths (approximately 2.4 bits). Using this model, you will be able to generate a sufficiently large string result without breaking any cryptography. An additional approach is to use hash table calculations to split the resulting number into halves and hash the result using the optimal sequence of the two halves.<n><n>You will need to approximate the length of string using matrix calculator.

Not only can graphs represent details about individual objects in a scene but they can capture the interactions between pairs of objects. We present a method for training a convolutional neural network such that it takes in an input image and produces a full graph. This is done end-to-end in a single stage with the use of associative embeddings. The network learns to simultaneously identify all of the elements that make up a graph and piece them together. We benchmark on the Visual Genome dataset, and report a Recall@50 of 9.7% compared to the prior state-of-the-art at 3.4%, a nearly threefold improvement on the challenging task of scene graph generation.<n><n>### Response:<n>		Graphs are the new noisy algorithms which are used to train visual genomes.

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>Given an abstract of a paper, generate a title for this paper such that conveys the key focus of the paper.<n><n>### Input:<n>Abstract: The four methods of illumination in the use of slit-lamp biomicroscopy of the anterior segment, described first by Vogt, are equally useful in the posterior part of the eye. Examination of the ocular fundus is more difficult. In particular, photography of the central and peripheral parts of the fundus demands additional technical arrangements if all the appearances of biomicroscopy are to be recorded.<n><n>### Response:<n>		Vogt and his colleagues described their method of focusing a laser beam in the invertebrate eye, which can be described as a unique optical method. The technique is similar to what is done in the human visual system with similar capabilities. Several examples of biomicroscopic imaging using experimental setups are described today in a series of papers named the Cell Reports and articles from Nature Biotechnology. These have made Vogt's method readily accessible to bioinformaticians by allowing for trained inventory calculations of (typically) just a couple of key parameters: pupil size, pattern intensity, retinoid status, mode (preserving or re-building the macroscopic images), and the sequence of light hitting the scan. Typical images created for biological studies can be used to guide techniques for later studies, which often require inspecting or reconstructing the entire eye area.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>In this task you are given a list of triplets of the form [subject, predicate, object] and the output should be a question based on the triplets but with the subject and/or object replaced with blanks (represented using two or more consecutive underscores). Triplet values encompassed in [*] are special tokens that can be replaced with synonyms. The objective is to construct a question in a manner that (a) captures the facts specified in at least one of the triplets, and (b) ideally contains a limited number of blanks such that it is a well-formed question that is easy to answer. A blank can represent a single word or a phrase.<n><n>### Input:<n>[['Fitzbillies', 'eatType', 'coffee shop'], ['Fitzbillies', 'food', 'French'], ['Fitzbillies', 'priceRange','moderate'], ['Fitzbillies', 'area', 'city centre']]<n><n>### Response:<n>		In this example, the objective is to construct a reasonably complete question that includes the facts specified in at most one triplet of the form [ subject, predicate, object] along with blanks. That said, it is possible that the objective could be any combination of more than one triplet. Therefore, it is recommended to use objects when possible.

While finite-horizon DECPOMDPs have enjoyed significant success, progress remains slow for the infinite-horizon case mainly due to the inherent complexity of optimizing stochastic controllers representing agent policies. We present a promising new class of algorithms for the infinite-horizon case, which recasts the optimization problem as inference in a mixture of DBNs. An attractive feature of this approach is the straightforward adoption of existing inference techniques in DBNs for solving DEC-POMDPs and supporting richer representations such as factored or continuous states and actions. We also derive the Expectation Maximization (EM) algorithm to optimize the joint policy represented as DBNs. Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>In this task, you are given a part of an article. Your task is to generate headline (title) for this text. Preferred headlines are under fifteen words.<n><n>### Input:<n>We develop a new model for Interactive Question Answering (IQA), using GatedRecurrent-Unit recurrent networks (GRUs) as encoders for statements and questions, and another GRU as a decoder for outputs. Distinct from previous work, our approach employs context-dependent word-level attention for more accurate statement representations and question-guided sentence-level attention for better context modeling. Employing these mechanisms, our model accurately understands when it can output an answer or when it requires generating a supplementary question for additional input. When available, user’s feedback is encoded and directly applied to update sentence-level attention to infer the answer. Extensive experiments on QA and IQA datasets demonstrate quantitatively the effectiveness of our model with significant improvement over conventional QA models.<n><n>### Response:<n>		The problem of generating headline and answering questions for articles is common in the research and development (R&D) industry. Two main approaches have been used for accomplishing this: first, employing the context dependent word level attention mechanism, and then using context dependent word level attention to optimize for user feedback. In our approach, preferred headlines are under fifteen words while other preferred headlines are under fifteen and over fifteen. Newer research results have shown that practicing word level attention leads to improvements in sentence accuracy. Two exploratory experiments examining sentence-level attention in article production already reinforce the efficacy of our approach. On QA, we apply user feedback directly to improve passage accuracy.

The objective is to construct a question in a manner that (a) captures the facts specified in at least one of the triplets, and (b) ideally contains a limited number of blanks such that it is a well-formed question that is easy to answer. Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:<n>In this task, you are given a part of an article. Your task is to generate headline (title) for this text. Preferred headlines are under fifteen words.<n><n>### Input:<n>The AGM theory of belief revision has be­ come an important paradigm for investigat­ ing rational belief changes. Unfortunately, researchers working in this paradigm have re­ stricted much of their attention to rather sim­ ple representations of belief states, namely logically closed sets of propositional sen­ tences. In our opinion, this has resulted in a too abstract categorisation of belief change operations: expansion, revision, or contrac­ tion. Occasionally, in the AGM paradigm, also probabilistic belief changes have been considered, and it is widely accepted that the probabilistic version of expansion is con­ ditioning. However, we argue that it may be more correct to view conditioning and expan­ sion as two essentially different kinds of belief change, and that what we call constraining is a better candidate for being considered prob­ abilistic expansion.<n><n>### Response:<n>		The AGM model of belief reverberation is most often associated with the probabilistic subject belief changes judg ment, and for a reason: by using a less abstract model of belief change, the focus is on the positivity and predictability of belief states, rather than the possibility of actual belief change. Another reason we think of physical belief changes—as opposed to purely experiential contact with a belief state—is that past research has shown the latter to influence the accessibility of further belief changes. We think revisiting these model concepts can be used to guide further search for constraints on our searches for likelihood of belief change, and for understanding the conditions under which new information about belief may emerge.

The objective is to construct a question in a manner that (a) captures the facts specified in at least one of the triplets, and (b) ideally contains a limited number of blanks such that it is a well-formed question that is easy to answer. A blank can represent a single word or a phrase.<n><n>### Input:<n>[['The Waterman', 'eatType','restaurant'], ['The Waterman', 'food', 'Fast food'], ['The Waterman', 'priceRange', 'high'], ['The Waterman', 'area', 'city centre'], ['The Waterman', 'familyFriendly', 'yes']]<n><n>### Response:<n>		The Waterman: [yes] The Waterman: no The Waterman: yes The Big Scoop: no The Big Scoop: yes

Once connected create a route for the current group to communicate through its encrypted channel to other group members. Once messages arrive onto the already encrypted channel then the group will have a choice to either accept them from the sender or accept them from the receiver. The receiver will then use its privkey to encrypt the messages with their private key for publication.

Try to use phrases and sentences from the story to compose your answer when possible.<n><n>### Input:<n>story: Sally's mother woke her up for school. Sally told her that she did not feel very well. Her mother checked her temperature. Her temperature showed she had a fever. So her mother took her to the doctor for medicine.<n> selected sentence: Sally's mother woke her up for school.<n><n>### Response:<n>		A causes/enables B, which is clearly a direct result of B. However, there is evidence that before B, the mother deliberately withheld information from her son - that her temperature showed she had a "fever". So Sally's mother knowingly allowed the child to have a fever, and told him he did not.

Preferred headlines are under fifteen words.<n><n>### Input:<n>We tackle the problem of inferring node labels in a partially labeled graph where each node in the graph has multiple label types and each label type has a large number of possible labels. Our primary example, and the focus of this paper, is the joint inference of label types such as hometown, current city, and employers, for users connected by a social network. Standard label propagation fails to consider the properties of the label types and the interactions between them. Our proposed method, called EDGEEXPLAIN, explicitly models these, while still enabling scalable inference under a distributed message-passing architecture. On a billion-node subset of the Facebook social network, EDGEEXPLAIN significantly outperforms label propagation for several label types, with lifts of up to 120% for recall@1 and 60% for recall@3.<n><n>### Response:<n>		EDGEEXPLAIN can outperform conventional label propagation in a fully labeled graph.

Twenty-five patients were anaesthetized with halothane at least 10 times in a year. No patient developed postoperative jaundice. Sixty-nine children were exposed to two halothane anaesthetics within 28 days on 149 occasions and serial estimations of serum liver enzyme concentrations were obtained. Minor increases in the concentrations of serum AST and ALT were recorded in 10.6% and 4.7% of patient entries, respectively. Postoperative GGT and SAP concentrations were increased in 2.7% of patient entries. Patients in whom enzyme values were increased before the first anaesthetic were no more likely than other subjects to develop further changes.<n><n>### Response:<n>		The title of this paper is "[A]neurysm for days after halothane anaesthesia using separate measurements of serum ALT and AST and WGT."
